Causal Hypothesis: Does regular physical exercise improve academic performance in students?

studies.methodology: Surveyed sports team participation, GPA, and standardized test scores, family income, parental education, and study time
studies.keyFindings: Students participating in organized sports had significantly higher GPAs (3.4 vs 2.8) and test scores compared to non-athletes
majorLimitations: Reverse causation possible (better students join sports teams)
Unmeasured confounders (self-discipline, family values, socioeconomic status)
Indirect intervention (sports teams may not be an appropriate proxy for regular physical exercise)

studies.methodology: Randomly assigned to high exercise (running wheels 6hrs daily) vs sedentary conditions for 8 weeks, then cognitive testing
studies.keyFindings: Exercise mice showed better spatial memory and learning, plus increased signs of synaptic plasticity in hippocampus
majorLimitations: Animal model (mice may have causal pathways that humans do not share)
Lab environment (absence of influential variables may make results inapplicable to a natural environment)
Indirect outcome (these metrics may not be appropriate as a proxy for academic performance)
